newsitem.title: USA: U.S. launches investigation into EU starch subsidies.
newsitem.headline: U.S. launches investigation into EU starch subsidies.

text.p: U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Monday said her agency launched an investigation into allegations that European Union subsidies for modified starch were hurting U.S. producers.

"I am very concerned about the difficulties that U.S. wheat gluten and starch producers are facing," Barshefsky said in a statement. "We intend to investigate the U.S. wheat gluten industry's claim that the EU uses one of its starch subsidy programs to cut off U.S. exports of modified starch to the EU."

The U.S. Trade Representative's office said the U.S. Wheat Gluten Industry Council asked for the investigation. The industry had alleged that EU subsidies benefited European production and export of wheat gluten to the United States. The U.S. wheat gluten industry produces both starch and gluten from wheat.
Barshefsky said a decision was made to launch the so-called Section 301 investigation into allegations that the EU starch production program was hurting the U.S. industry.
"The decision to initiate this investigation exemplifies the commitment of this administration to remain vigilant in monitoring the practices of our trading partners," Barshefsky said.

She said no 301 investigtion would be launched into allegations concerning subsidized wheat gluten. She said the USTR would continue working with the U.S. industry to determine whether futher action was needed. She said the United States would seek consultations with the EU under a July 1996 trade agreement on grains.
